author: @duszan2

comment:
"...the collective good of open source can help fight that."

It's a question of " Should we sacrifice a few thousand lives by opening the floodgates, enter a potential war with bad actors and then work towards a future where we win or should we close the doors now, hoping that the actors behind the tech are good ( Lex says they are ) and save all the lives?" 

The word "save" here is talking about the companies and individuals out there who are vulnerable to scams and hacks.

I'm personally with Sam Altman and Satya Nadella. It's better if they have the keys to my data. It's basically known devil and unknown devil at this point so I'd go with known devils.

comment: I think the day I tried GPT was the coolest day ever in my life. I get that it makes all kinds of mistakes, but man, how can anyone not be excited about it? That's beyond me. It's not like those old pre-programmed text game-style conversational bots; it's literally like Jarvis, sort of, almost there. Like it's not AGI, but it's more than enough to go on. It's like I'm living in some future novel of the 60s or 70s. It's great! What the OpenAI team has done is amazing and will definitely change the world. Just don't let it be accessible to totalitarian countries, and it'll be alright boys.

comment:
Man, ChatGPT is pretty crazy.
I just watched it write a UI form for Android to take user profile information in the latest BP library...it did a scary good job.
When I expressed my concern about losing my job, it assured me of the ways AI can be a tool to us software engineers, allowing us to spend more time on the creative process vs the weeds and as I move into more architecture vs development this aligns well with my wants. I'm now more excited than scared because the days of spending so much time on little snippets of code are nearly over!
We will not be losing any jobs however.

author: @FRANKWHITE1996

comment:
I have discussed the following with ChatGPT and it generally agreed with my reasoning, it would be great to hear Sam's thoughts on this:

When it comes to developing AI tools, the widespread use of English language could be seen as a significant advantage. English is spoken by a large proportion of the world's population, and is used in many different countries and contexts, providing a diverse and extensive data set for training AI models. Additionally, the dominance of English-speaking countries in AI research and development means that there is a wealth of talent and expertise available in the language.

In contrast, the popularity of the Chinese language could present some challenges for AI development in China. While Chinese is the most spoken language in the world, it is primarily spoken in China and a few other countries, limiting the availability of diverse and high-quality data for training AI models. Additionally, restrictions on freedom of speech and creativity in China could hinder the development of truly innovative and versatile AI tools, as experimentation and risk-taking are essential for creativity and innovation.

author: @nic.trades

comment:
Just to talk on the section around 1:08:00 about AI consciousness. We should never lose sight of the fact that as biological beings, we have existed in our current form for a fairly short time compared to the history of life on this planet. Then from that point of comprehension, acknowledge the comparative levels of intelligence we see in some other species that have also been on this biological evolutionary journey.

We are the clear outlier, and orders of magnitude more capable in the application of our intelligence, but consciousness is not purely the preserve of the human condition. Like intelligence it seems to have levels to it in the biological story around us, so it appears related to the general evolutionary process that is the history of life on this planet.

As humans we evolved the best 'user interface', our ability to communicate, and that must have contributed to our position of dominance in the evolutionary biological tree.
